facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 2137 of 1968 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 2137 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated April 5, 1968 of Judicial Commissioners Court, Goa, Daman and Diu in Writ Petition No. 9 of 1967.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 5, 1968 of the Judicial Commissioners Court , G a, Daman and Diu in Writ Petition No. 9 of1967.

facts.text: Appellant challenged levy of export duty of Rs. 98044 on 9804.40 metric tonnes of iron ore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the levy of export duty of Rs. 98044 on 9804-40 metric tonnes of iron ore shipped on S.S. Ardenode on 3 August, 1966 at the rate of Rs. 10 per metric tonne.

facts.text: Iron ore shipped on S.S. Ardenode on 3 August 1966 at rate of Rs. 10 per metric tonne.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the levy of export duty of Rs. 98044 on 9804-40 metric tonnes of iron ore shipped on S.S. Ardenode on 3 August, 1966 at the rate of Rs. 10 per metric tonne.

facts.text: Appellant filed shipping bill in triplicate on 26 July 1966 for 10,160 metric tonnes of iron ore.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant on 26 July, 1966 filed shipping bill in triplicate before the Joint Chief Controller of Imports and Exports Panaji, Goa for the purpose of obtaining export licence in respect of 10,160 metric tonnes of iron ore.

facts.text: Export licence granted to appellant on 28 July 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On 28 July, 1966 export licence was granted to the appellant.

facts.text: Hiralal Co., agents of S.S. Ardenode, applied for entry outwards on 30 July 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Hiralal Co. agents of the vessel S. S. Ardenode made an application to the Assistant Collector of Customs, Marmagoa for the grant of entry outwards to the said vessel to load iron ore.

facts.text: Assistant Collector of Customs, Marmagoa granted entry outwards to S.S. Ardenode on 30 July 1966.

anchor.surface_text: On 30 July, 1966 the Assistant Collector of Customs, Marmagoa made an order granting entry outwards to the said vessel S.S. Ardenode and also gave permission to ship cargo on board the said vessel.

facts.text: Appellant presented shipping bills dated 26 July 1966 to Customs on 1 August 1966 under section 50 of Customs Act 1962.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 August, 1966 the appellant presented to the Customs authorities under section 50 of the Customs Act, 1962,  herein- after called the Act , shipping bills in triplicate, dated 26 July, 1966.

facts.text: Appellant subscribed to declaration of truth of contents on shipping bills.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in accordance with the provisions of section 50 of the Act at the foot of the shipping bill subscribed to a declaration as to the truth of the companytents of the shipping bills.

facts.text: Customs authorities endorsed shipping bill on 1 August 1966 with rotation No. 730, Let export after examination if necessary, E.F. No. 3/1/8/1966.

anchor.surface_text: On 1 August, 1966 the Customs authorities made these entries on the shipping- bill rotation No. 730 Sd 1 August, 1966 Let export after examination if necessary Sd - 1 August, 1966 and. E.F.No. 3/1/8/1966.

facts.text: Customs authorities made further endorsements on shipping bill on 2 August 1966: PI as usual, checked des Inspected the lot-2-barges-checlkeci des and Pd in full.

anchor.surface_text: On 2 August 1966 the Customs authorities made further endorsements on the shipping bill. These endorsements were PI as usual and checked des Inspected the lot-2-barges- checlkeci des and Pd in full.

facts.text: Ministry of Commerce issued notification on 2 August 1966 under section 4-A of Indian Tariff Act 1934 amending second schedule, introducing item 28 lumpy iron ore at Rs. 10 per tonne.

anchor.surface_text: On 2 August, 1966 there was a numberification issued, by the Ministry of Commerce in exercise of powers companyferred by section 4-A of the Indian Tariff Act, 1934 amending the second schedule to the Tariff Act. The relevant item in the said schedule introduced by way amendment is 28 and the name of the article is lumpy iron ore and the rate of duty is Rs. 10 per tonne.

facts.text: S.S. Ardenode arrived at Marmagoa at 23.20 hours on 2 August 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The S.S. Ardenode arrived at Marmagoa at 23.20 hours on 2 August, 1966.

facts.text: S.S. Ardenode arrived at Marmagoa Inner Harbour on 3 August 1966 at 07.50 hours.

anchor.surface_text: The vessel arrived at Marmagoa Inner Harbour on  3  August, 1966 at 07.50 hour-,.

facts.text: Vessel commenced loading cargo on 3 August 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The vessel companymenced loading the cargo on 3 August, 1966.

facts.text: Customs issued notice to appellant on 28 January 1967 demanding export duty Rs. 98044 under section 28 of Customs Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Customs authorities on 28 January, 1967 issued a numberice to the appellant numberifying that the goods actually shipped by the appellant were subject to export duty at the rate of Rs. 10 Per metric tonne and the custom duty amounting to Rs. 98044 which was number levied in respect of the companysignment was due from the appellant and the appellant was called upon in accordance with section 28 of the Act as to why the amount should number be recover- ed from the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant contended that shipping bill presented and entry outwards given prior to 2 August 1966, so no duty payable.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended before the Customs authorities that the shipping bill was presented to the Customs authorities and the entry outwards to the ship S.S. Ardenode was given prior to 2 August, 1966 when numberduty was payable in respect of the export of the goods in question.

facts.text: Customs authorities held on 19 April 1967 that under section 16(1) shipping bill deemed presented on 3 August 1966 when vessel arrived, levy duty.

anchor.surface_text: The Customs authorities on 19 April, 1967 held that by virtue of the provisions of section 16 1  of the Act the shipping bill shall be deemed to have been presented at the earliest on 3 August, 1966 when the vessel in question arrived.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition under Article 226 in Judicial Commissioner Court, Goa, Daman and Diu.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant impeached the order of the Customs authorities under Article 226 of the Constitution in the Court of the Judicial Commissioner, Goa, Daman and Diu, Panaji.

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner upheld order of Customs authorities.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner upheld the order of the Customs authorities.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed appeal, set aside notice dated 28 January 1967 and order dated 19 April 1967.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the appellant is entitled to an order cancelling the numberice dated 28 January, 1967 by which the Customs authorities demand duty from the appellant. The order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside. There will be a writ setting aside the numberice dated 28 January, 1967 and an order for bearing the respondents from taking any steps or proceedings pursuant to the numberice dated 28 January, 1967. There will also be an order quashing the order of the Assistant Collector of Customs dated 19 April, 1967 which gave effect to the numberice and held the appellant liable to pay the export duty. The appeal Is allowed.

facts.text: It is common case that shipping bill presented on 1 August 1966.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is companymon case that the shipping bill was presented to the Customs authorities on 1 August, 1966 and the Customs authorities made several endorsements on the shipping bill on the same day.

facts.text: Appellant impeached vires of notification under section 4-A.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be stated that the appellant impeached the vires of the numberification.

facts.text: Shipping bill described goods as free goods and export licence granted thereon.

anchor.surface_text: The shipping bill described the goods as free goods. Export licence was also granted on that shipping bill.
The appellant impeached the order of the Customs authorities under Article 226 of the Constitution in the Court of the Judicial Commissioner, Goa, Daman and Diu, Panaji.

The Customs authorities on 28 January, 1967 issued a notice to the appellant notifying that the goods actually shipped by the appellant were subject to export duty at the rate of Rs. 10 Per metric tonne and the custom duty amounting to Rs. 98044 which was not levied in respect of the consignment was due from the appellant and the appellant was called upon in accordance with section 28 of the Act as to why the amount should not be recovered from the appellant.

concepts.unlisted_description: Provision for recovery of duty not levied or short-levied

anchor.surface_text: On 2 August, 1966 there was a notification issued, by the Ministry of Commerce in exercise of powers conferred by section 4-A of the Indian Tariff Act, 1934 amending the second schedule to the Tariff Act. The relevant item in the said schedule introduced by way amendment is 28 and the name of the article is lumpy iron ore and the rate of duty is Rs. 10 per tonne.

concepts.interpretation: Notification amending schedule to impose export duty on lumpy iron ore effective from 2 August 1966

anchor.surface_text: On 1 August, 1966 the appellant presented to the Customs authorities under section 50 of the Customs Act, 1962,  hereinafter called the Act , shipping bills in triplicate, dated 26 July, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 is as follows - 16 1 . The rate of duty and tariff valuation, if any, applicable to any export goods, shall be the rate and valuation in force-  a  in the case of goods entered for export under section 50, on the date on which a shipping bill or a bill of export in respect of such goods is presented under that section  b  in the case of any other goods, on the date of payment of duty Provided that if the shipping bill has been presented before the date of entry outwards of the vessel by which the goods are to be exported, the shipping bill shall be deemed to have been presented on the date of such entry outwords.

concepts.interpretation: Rate of duty determined by date shipping bill presented under s50; proviso deems presentation on entry outwards date only if presented before that date. Here, presented after entry outwards on 30 July, so actual date 1 Aug applies, pre-notification.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: follows 50 1 . The exporter of any goods shall make entry thereof by presenting to the proper officer in the case of goods to be exported in a vessel

concepts.unlisted_description: Date for determination of rate of duty and tariff valuation of export goods

anchor.surface_text: Section 51 of the Act is as follows - Where the proper officer is satisfied that any goods entered for export are not prohibited goods and the exporter has paid the duty, if any, assessed thereon and any charges payable under this Act in respect of the same, the proper officer may make an order permitting clearance and loading of goods for exportation.

concepts.interpretation: Clearance for export after satisfaction, duty payment

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the prescribed form. The exporter of any goods, while presenting a shipping bill or bill of export,

anchor.surface_text: The relevant provisions for the purpose of the present appeal are to be found in section 16 which deals with date for determination of rate of duty and tariff valuation of export goods and sections 39, 50 and 51 which deal with loading of export goods on vessel and clearance of goods for exportation.

Under the provisions of section 38 of the 1878 Act the Customs authorities had power to apply the rate in force on the date of the arrival of the vessel. Under section 16 of the 1962 Act it is not permissible to do so.

concepts.interpretation: Old provision allowed rate on arrival date; new Act does not

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: el the shipping bill must be deemed to have been delivered on the date on which that vessel arrived or entry outwards was given whichever was later. U

issues.text: whether shipment and export of iron ore by the appellant became liable to the said duty introduced on 2 August, 1966

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner upheld the order of the Customs authorities. The entire controversy in the present appeal is whether shipment and export of iron ore by the appellant became liable to the said duty introduced on 2 August, 1966.

issues.text: Whether the notification issued under section 4-A of the Indian Tariff Act, 1934 is ultra vires

anchor.surface_text: The appellant therefore contended the notification under section 4-A of the Tariff Act 1934 was not applicable to the consignment and no duty was payable in respect of the export of the having regard to the provisions of section 16 of the Customs Act. It may also be stated that the appellant impeached the vires of the notification.

issues.text: Whether under section 16 of the 1962 Act the Customs authorities had power to apply the rate in force on the date of the arrival of the vessel

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of section 38 of the 1878 Act the Customs authorities had power to apply the rate in force on the date of the arrival of the vessel. Under section 16 of the 1962 Act it is not permissible to do so. The statute does not contain such a provision.

arguments.claim: Under s16(1)(a), rate of duty is that in force on date shipping bill presented under s50

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 is as follows - 16 1 . The rate of duty and tariff valuation, if any, applicable to any export goods, shall be the rate and valuation in force-  a  in the case of goods entered for export under section 50, on the date on which a shipping bill or a bill of export in respect of such goods is presented under that section  b  in the case of any other goods, on the date of payment of duty Provided that if the shipping bill has been presented before the date of entry outwards of the vessel by which the goods are to be exported, the shipping bill shall be deemed to have been presented on the date of such entry outwords.

arguments.claim: Proviso to s16 deems presentation on entry outwards date only if shipping bill presented before that date; here presented after, so actual date applies

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is common case that the shipping bill was presented to the Customs authorities on 1 August, 1966 and the Customs authorities made several endorsements on the shipping bill on the same day.

arguments.claim: Under s38 of 1878 Act, rate could be on vessel arrival date; s16 of 1962 Act does not permit this

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of section 38 of the 1878 Act the Customs authorities had power to apply the rate in force on the date of the arrival of the vessel. Under section 16 of the 1962 Act it is not permissible to do so. The statute does not contain such a provision.

arguments.claim: Customs acted without jurisdiction by deeming entry outwards date as vessel arrival date

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the Customs authorities, in the impugned order acted without jurisdiction in imposing duty on the export by holding that the date of entry outwards of the vessel was the date when the vessel arrived.

holdings.text: The shipment and export of iron ore by the appellant did not become liable to the export duty introduced on 2 August 1966.

anchor.surface_text: The Judicial Commissioner upheld the order of the Customs authorities. The entire controversy in the present appeal is whether shipment and export of iron ore by the appellant became liable to the said duty introduced on 2 August, 1966.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under section 16(1)(a) of Customs Act 1962, rate of duty determined by date of shipping bill presentation on 1 August 1966, after entry outwards on 30 July 1966, so proviso deeming to entry outwards date inapplicable; notification effective 2 August does not apply.

holdings.text: The Customs authorities acted without jurisdiction in imposing duty by holding that the date of entry outwards was the date of vessel arrival.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the Customs authorities, in the impugned order acted without jurisdiction in imposing duty on the export by holding that the date of entry outwards of the vessel was the date when the vessel arrived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 16 provides fictional date only for entry outwards if shipping bill presented before that date; here presented after, and no provision links to vessel arrival date.

holdings.text: Under section 16 of the Customs Act 1962, Customs authorities do not have power to apply the rate of duty in force on the date of vessel arrival.

anchor.surface_text: Under the provisions of section 38 of the 1878 Act the Customs authorities had power to apply the rate in force on the date of the arrival of the vessel. Under section 16 of the 1962 Act it is not permissible to do so. The statute does not contain such a provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Unlike section 38 of Sea Customs Act 1878, section 16 of 1962 Act lacks provision for rate based on arrival; limited to presentation date or deemed entry outwards date under proviso.

holdings.text: The proviso to section 16(1) deems shipping bill presented on entry outwards date only if actually presented before that date.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is common case that the shipping bill was presented to the Customs authorities on 1 August, 1966 and the Customs authorities made several endorsements on the shipping bill on the same day.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry outwards granted 30 July 1966 prior to presentation on 1 August 1966; proviso condition not satisfied, actual presentation date governs.

holdings.text: The notice dated 28 January 1967 demanding duty and order dated 19 April 1967 are quashed; respondents barred from proceeding pursuant thereto.

anchor.surface_text: For the foregoing reasons the appellant is entitled to an order cancelling the notice dated 28 January, 1967 by which the Customs authorities demand duty from the appellant. The order of the Judicial Commissioner is set aside.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Misapplication of section 16 by customs and lower court; correct date under statute is pre-notification.
